page.title: 07The Mop, Warwick.
page.content: Every year for two weekends in October, Warwick Town Centre is closed to traffic and a large fair or 'mop' takes place. The origin of this fair dates back to the plague of 1349 when one third of the population of England died. This left a shortage of labour particulary in the agricultural units known as manors and caused a general upheaval and movement of farm workers. To regulate this matter parliament passed a statute stating that men should attend at the nearest market day to the end of Sept. To ply for the hire for the following year. Roasting of an ox which is still carried out, probably arose from the need to feed such a large gathering of people and following this, general festivities took place.The runaway 'mop' was held a week later to give men not yet hired a second chance.This tradition is kept
